Sonny (Dev Patel).Action: Deposits a paint pot and brush on a parapet, then races off across the rooftop.
Welcomes travellers enthusiastically with arms spread wide, saying 'Welcome to India!!!'
Leads Madge into the hotel, tries to present the building positively despite its flaws, proudly highlighting its character and longevity.
Attempts to soften the lack of a door in Madge’s room by focusing on freedom rather than the missing door, showing care to frame negatives in a positive light.
Avoids direct apology or acknowledgment of the problem with the missing door; instead redirects conversation with humor and optimism.
Offers a vision of the future to reassure Mrs. Ainslie despite current shortcomings.
Demonstrates understanding with the saying 'everything will be alright in the end,' showing patience and optimism.
Agrees to provide a full refund if desired, showing willingness to honor customer concerns.
Promises refund but defers timing to 'straight away in three months,' which may reduce perceived sincerity or immediacy.
Offers a vision of the future for the hotel despite current shortcomings, showing optimism and strategic thinking.
Promises a full refund but sets an unrealistic timeframe of three months, which undermines immediate trustworthiness.
Uses an Indian saying to inspire patience and confidence, demonstrating cultural awareness and communication skills.
Prepares a special welcome dinner, presenting it as a gesture of hospitality and care for his guests, despite the mismatched and difficult circumstances.
Gives a sincere and touching speech about the hotel and honoring the guests' decision to spend their remaining time there.
Fails to notice Norman’s unwell condition during his speech, showing a momentary lack of attentiveness and sensitivity.
Responds calmly and responsibly when Norman collapses, asserting control and providing information that Norman has died.
Attempts to serve a British roast dinner personally, showing enthusiasm and a desire to please guests.
Fails to notice Norman’s declining health and continued his welcome speech obliviously.
Responds quickly and decisively to Norman’s collapse by asserting medical knowledge, checking pulse, and confirming death.
Covers Norman's face to preserve his dignity at a distressing moment.
Attempts to cover the man's face respectfully with a napkin to preserve dignity at a difficult moment.
Shakes his watch to check if it is still working, showing practical responsiveness in the situation.
His battered old car has broken down in a chaotic environment.
Waves away kids swarming at the car windows, trying to protect Jean who looks traumatized.
Attempts to fix the broken down car by aiming a couple of kicks at the engine.
Waves away a horde of kids swarming the car, managing the chaotic situation as best he can.
Pushes Muriel through the hospital lobby and engages in discussion with doctors, showing initiative and responsibility.
Turns to see Muriel has vanished, indicating a lapse in supervision or awareness.
Greets Sunaina warmly, kisses her, and expresses desire to spend time together despite work constraints.
Invites Sunaina to leave her job and work for him, showing care and willingness to support her.
Acknowledges financial limitations openly, showing sincerity and vulnerability.
Responds to Sunaina's teasing about finances with light humor rather than defensiveness.
Arrives on motorcycle with a bag of marigolds, suggesting hands-on involvement and industriousness.
Confidently invites Sunaina to leave her job and work for him, showing leadership and initiative.
Admits he cannot afford much, showing honesty but also limitations in resources.
Renting a hotel room for meeting instead of having Sunaina stay at hotel he owns because some rooms are occupied, implying practical management awareness.
Responds to Sunaina's nitpicking about paying guests with casual dismissal, indicating slight defensiveness or lack of detail focus.
Brimming with confidence, walks a wealthy investor around the hotel grounds and presents plans for the Phase Two Development with clear business intent.
Attempts to present the hotel positively and introduces Mrs Donnelly to the investor with a polite request despite her grim response.
Uses a humorous metaphor ('the wheel is spinning, but the hamster is dead') to describe the hotel's situation.
Shows surprise and warmth by addressing Mrs Kapoor affectionately as 'Mummyji' when seeing her unexpectedly.
Requests his mother not to open his desk drawers but is unable to prevent her, showing a moment of vulnerability but no harshness.
Walking a wealthy investor confidently around the hotel grounds and pitching the hotel's revival, despite vagueness in details.
Admits openly to Mr. Maruthi he is 'not a details man' and gives non-specific answers about the number of rooms.
Attempts to steer the investor by managing the encounter with a guest despite awkwardness of guest’s blunt negative comment.
Uses a cryptic metaphor 'The wheel is spinning but the hamster is dead' showing some candid awareness of the situation.
Confronts his mother firmly about her rummaging through his desk and sets boundaries.
Expresses confidence in his entrepreneurial dream and defends his independence in choosing a partner, showing respect for his own feelings and boundaries.
Jokes about Young Wasim's dicky back to politely refuse carrying luggage, indicating considerate awareness of others' limitations.
Engages in a respectful, if somewhat playful, debate with his mother about marriage and personal choices, showing both sincerity and firmness.
Expresses a visionary business idea to 'out-source old age' beyond British clients, showing ambition and strategic thinking.
Acknowledges that success requires long-term strategy and patience, indicating realistic understanding of business growth.
Confidently asserts personal choice in marriage without seeking permission, showing self-assuredness.
Refers to a practical limitation (Young Wasim’s dicky back) to avoid carrying luggage, demonstrating awareness of employee wellbeing and operational details.
Shares a personal memory about his father and expresses warmth towards Sunaina by saying his father would have liked her
Shows protective or somewhat dismissive attitude towards his mother’s disapproval of the marriage
Reflects on his father's wisdom about the well and the people met there, displays emotional insight and connection.
Comforts Sunaina about his mother's disapproval realistically by acknowledging social and economic factors.
Shows awareness of social constraints and familial expectations regarding marriage.
Expresses complex feelings for Sunaina, acknowledging that his love cannot be reduced to a single word.
States that Sunaina is too good for him, implying low self-esteem rather than dislike or rejection.
Focuses on business progress and optimism about investor and hotel success, showing responsibility and dedication.
Finds a new investor and expresses optimism about moving forward with Phase Two of the hotel project, demonstrating proactive business initiative.
Attempts to explain business dynamics about not standing still but stumbles in the phrasing, indicating some lack of confidence or clarity.
Avoids directly answering Sunaina’s personal question about love, indicating hesitance or emotional evasiveness.
Expresses self-doubt by telling Sunaina she is 'too good' for him, which shows a lack of confidence rather than competence.
Charges rates for job but cannot help Evelyn make ends meet after debts.
Persistently tries to contact Sunaina, expressing longing and affection despite her reluctance.
Jokes warmly with Jay over the phone, showing friendly rapport.
Says to Sunaina 'Neither am I. Absolutely not. There is no shame. You do not have to sneak.'
Adds 'All the same, if you did want to be very quiet, and not let anyone see you, it couldn’t hurt.' showing consideration for her feelings.
Realizes the ringing telephone and urgently searches for it amid paperwork.
Excitedly shares the news that the hotel telephones are working, eager to tell everyone and his mother.
Announces enthusiastically to others that progress is happening at the hotel, specifically that the telephones are working again.
Rushes excitedly to tell everyone the good news and his mother, showing confidence and proactive communication.
Bursts into the room to defend Sunaina and Madge, apologizes sincerely and tries to quickly resolve the embarrassing situation by ensuring Sunaina leaves discreetly.
Races quickly to address a sudden problem, tries to manage a delicate situation by apologizing and attempting to defuse tension.
Fails to prevent embarrassment or confusion, reacts awkwardly to Sunaina's nakedness and the situation spiraling out of control.
Steps forward reluctantly to defend Sunaina by saying 'Because this ... is my Sunaina.'
Clarifies to his mother that Sunaina was with him, not with Mrs Hardcastle, attempting to protect Sunaina's reputation.
Steps forward reluctantly to clarify Sunaina’s position to Mrs Kapoor, attempting to manage a difficult family confrontation.
Fails to prevent Sunaina’s humiliation and does not effectively navigate the confrontation to a positive resolution.
Confidently presents a clear, direct business request to his investor, Mr Maruthi, asking for funding to begin Phase Two Development of the hotel immediately.
Speaks quietly and vulnerably to his mother about her cruelty and compares himself to his father, showing emotional openness.
Insists on trying to save the hotel despite doubt and criticism, showing perseverance and faith in the people relying on him.
Leaves after a tense exchange without escalating conflict, showing restraint.
Advocates for a small injection of funds to turn things around despite skepticism from Mrs Kapoor.
Speaks quietly and emotionally when confronted by Mrs Kapoor about past failures.
Rejects the easier but smaller life offered by Mrs Kapoor and chooses to leave, implying determination and confidence in his vision.
Attempts to warn Evelyn about upcoming changes before she discovers them herself.
Delivers news of the hotel’s closing and residents’ departure, framing it positively.
Attempts to deliver important news about the hotel's closing and inhabitants leaving, trying to be transparent and proactive.
Appears at a loss and somewhat confused after talking to Evelyn, indicating uncertainty or lack of preparedness.
Prioritizes the happiness and future of his girlfriend Sunaina over his own desires, believing she deserves better than him and restraining from expressing love to avoid holding her back.
Speaks self-deprecatingly about his life as a series of disasters and catastrophes, showing humility and vulnerability.
Abruptly dismisses Evelyn’s advice with humor and leaves quickly on his bike instead of engaging further.
Accepts arranged marriage plans without apparent resistance despite personal feelings.
Acknowledges lack of personal triumphs and expresses low self-confidence.
Confesses deep love for Sunaina but chooses not to express it, believing she deserves better.
Responds to Evelyn’s challenge with humor and promptly takes action to find Sunaina.
Roars through the streets on his bike.
Roars into the forecourt, rushes into the building, runs up many stairs calling out for Sunaina.
Roars into the forecourt, quickly gets off his bike, and runs up multiple floors in the call centre to urgently find Sunaina.
Expresses deep love and commitment openly and sincerely to Sunaina, admitting past insecurities.
Harshly tells Jay to 'fuck off' despite Jay trying to help.
Hopes to become better friends with Jay, his future brother-in-law, showing openness to relationship-building.
Persists to reach Sunaina despite being out of breath and physically exhausted.
Clearly states what he wants and takes initiative to communicate his feelings.
Uses strong, direct language to convey his determination and emotional clarity.
Exhibits some social awareness by attempting to clarify his feelings and repair relationships.
Could be seen as emotionally impulsive or overly confrontational in telling Jay to 'fuck off' but this reflects confidence more than incompetence.
Navigates quickly through city traffic and takes a prompt U-turn upon encountering a traffic jam due to the Ganeshi procession.
Openly declares his love for Sunaina in front of his mother and states his wish to marry her despite family opposition.
Addresses his mother respectfully as 'Mummyji' and tries to engage her warmly.
Admits failure regarding the Marigold Hotel but remains sincere and vulnerable about his feelings and dreams.
Openly admits failure about the hotel business but courageously expresses his love and intention to marry Sunaina to his mother.
Persistently tries to gain acceptance from his mother despite her clear refusal and forbidding of his relationship.
Fails to technically manage the hotel successfully, as indicated by it 'crumbling into dust.'
Races through the streets on his motorbike with Sunaina, confident and skillful in handling the vehicle.
